entry.title: Re: Problem with requirement types in strategy group 30
entry.content:
No, you cannot register planned independent requirements (PIRs) with strategy group 30 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition because the requirement type is blank. Unlike ECC, where strategy group 30 was linked to requirement type LSF, the Cloud edition does not provide this assignment by default. To enable PIRs, you must use a different planning strategy group (such as 40 or 10) or configure requirement type assignments in the configuration environment.

So what you can do is reassign your material master from strategy group 30 to 40 (VSF) if you need PIRs with sales order consumption, or to 10 (PD) if you only need pure make-to-stock PIRs. This will resolve the error and allow PIR registration.

entry.title: 10 reasons to trust the SAP Business Transformation Center with your data migration
entry.content:
We get it. When SAP launches something new, the skepticism is real. "Another product that experiments on customers?" "Will this actually work in production?" "Does SAP really understand what we're dealing with on the ground?" These are fair questions, especially when you're responsible for migrating mission-critical ERP systems.

SAP Business Transformation Center (SAP BTC) is the new kid on the block for data migration, but it's far from immature. Here's what sets it apart and why you can trust it with your most important projects.

 

1. Built by People Who've Been in the Trenches

SAP BTC wasn't dreamed up in an ivory tower. The product owners have decades of hands-on experience in data transformation projects. They've seen what works, what fails, and what keeps consultants up at night. That expertise is baked into every feature and workflow.

 

2. Built on Proven Methodologies, Not Experiments

SAP BTC leverages battle-tested data migration approaches that have been refined over many years. Take Selective Data Transition (SDT) as one example‚Äîit's been used successfully in thousands of projects by tens of thousands of customers for more than two decades. SAP BTC builds on these, giving you the confidence that comes with proven strategies.

 

3. No More Dependency on Scarce Expertise

One of the biggest bottlenecks in data migration projects? Finding consultants with the right knowledge. SAP BTC provides intelligent guidance based on actual data analyzed in your source system. You can get started quickly without waiting months for specialized expertise to become available.

 

4. End-to-End Coverage

SAP BTC handles the entire migration journey, from analyzing your source system to validating data in the target. You're not stitching together multiple tools and hoping they play nicely. Everything you need is in one place, reducing complexity and integration risks.

 

5. Modern User Experience That Doesn't Feel Like Legacy SAP

SAP BTC offers a genuinely modern, intuitive user experience based on Fiori Elements. Your team won't need extensive training just to navigate the interface or understand what's happening.

 

6. Smart Orchestration with Proven Technology

SAP BTC combines cloud capabilities with the reliability of the ABAP execution engine, the same technology powering the SAP Landscape Transformation Replication Server (SLT). This isn't experimental tech. It's perfectly suited for table-oriented data migration and has been proven in countless enterprise deployments.

 

7. Pre-Built Content from Years of Real-World Projects

SAP Services has been refining migration content and methodological knowledge across almost all industries, regions, and customer groups for years‚Äînot in a lab, but in real customer environments facing real challenges. SAP BTC packages this hard-won knowledge into predefined content you can use immediately. You're not starting from scratch; you're building on collective wisdom earned in the field.

 

8. Data Footprint Reduction Made Easy

Migrating to SAP S/4HANA is the perfect time to clean house. SAP BTC makes it straightforward to reduce your data footprint by identifying what's truly needed and what can be discarded. Less data means faster migrations, lower costs, and better performance in your new system.

 

9. Fact-Based Decision Making

No more guessing or relying on gut feelings. SAP BTC provides data-driven insights that let you make informed decisions throughout the project. You can scope accurately, plan realistically, and set stakeholder expectations based on actual system analysis, not assumptions.

 

10. Test with Confidence, Deploy with Certainty

SAP BTC's versioning concept allows for rapid test cycles. More importantly, a configuration that works in testing can be used exactly as-is for go-live. And here's a crucial point: migration happens between your source and target systems. No sensitive data enters the cloud, addressing a major security concern many organizations have.

 

Ready to Look Under the Hood?

SAP Business Transformation Center represents a new generation of migration tooling, but it's built on decades of proven methodology and expertise. If you're planning a move to S/4HANA and want to explore how SAP BTC can make your journey smoother, check out our SAP Help Portal or visit the official SAP BTC page in the SAP Support Portal for detailed documentation and resources. 

The data migration challenge hasn't gotten easier, but the tools finally have.

entry.title: How AI Transforms Customer Experience (CX) in SAP Product Lines of Business
entry.content:
Introduction:

Customer experience (CX) has become the cornerstone of business success. In today‚Äôs digital economy, customers expect fast, personalized, and seamless interactions. Artificial Intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing how organizations deliver these experiences, and SAP‚Äôs Product Lines of Business (LoB) are leveraging AI to make this transformation possible.

1. Why AI Matters for Customer Service CX

  • Personalization at Scale: AI enables businesses to understand customer behavior and preferences, delivering tailored recommendations and solutions.
  • 24/7 Availability: AI-powered chatbots and virtual assistants ensure customers receive support anytime, anywhere.
  • Predictive Insights: AI can anticipate customer needs, reducing friction and improving satisfaction.
  • Efficiency and Cost Reduction: Automating repetitive tasks frees up human agents for complex issues, improving productivity.

2. AI Use Cases in Customer Service

  • Intelligent Chatbots: Handle FAQs, troubleshoot issues, and escalate complex cases.
  • Sentiment Analysis: Understand customer emotions in real-time to adapt responses.
  • Predictive Service: AI predicts potential issues before they occur, enabling proactive support.
  • Voice and Conversational AI: Enhance call center interactions with natural language processing.

3. How SAP LoB Integrates AI for CX

SAP‚Äôs LoBs (e.g., SAP Customer Experience, SAP Service Cloud, SAP Commerce Cloud) embed AI capabilities to deliver superior CX:

  • SAP Service Cloud: AI-driven ticket routing and automated case resolution.
  • SAP Commerce Cloud: Personalized product recommendations using machine learning.
  • SAP Sales Cloud: Intelligent lead scoring and next-best-action suggestions.
  • SAP Business AI: Embedded AI services across SAP applications for predictive analytics and automation.

4. Business Impact of AI in SAP CX

  • Improved Customer Satisfaction: Faster resolution and personalized engagement.
  • Operational Efficiency: Reduced handling time and optimized resource allocation.
  • Revenue Growth: Better upselling and cross-selling through AI-driven insights.
  • Scalability: AI enables businesses to handle growing customer demands without proportional cost increases.

5. Future Outlook

AI will continue to evolve with generative AI, conversational intelligence, and hyper-personalization. SAP‚Äôs commitment to embedding AI into its LoBs ensures businesses stay ahead in delivering exceptional CX.

Conclusion:

AI is not just a technology trend‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategic enabler for customer-centric organizations. By integrating AI into SAP‚Äôs Product LoBs, businesses can transform customer service into a competitive advantage.

entry.title: Re: Missing Legally Required Company Address Fields for E...
entry.content:
Hello @nbek 

Thank you for your question

Answer to question 1:

Generally, you do not need the Location API to retrieve the seller‚Äôs address. This is because the source for the company code address is through the company‚Äôs Code API. The public cloud includes AddressID and other legal attributes. I therefore suggest you use the AddressID to read the actual address from Business Address Services. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3da95a01a7d44118786bb83b55c464c.html  for more details.

You can get the official company code addresses that is maintained in S4 by:

  • Calling API_COMPANYCODE_SRV to issue you CompanyCode and then read AddressID through it.
  • Calling a released address by using that AddressID to enable you get details like street, house number Postcode, etc.

Alternatively, a supported pattern is also a legal entity that is maintained as a BP. If you use the legal entity as a BP that is mapped to the Compan Code, you have the possibility to retrieve the address with API_BUSINESS_PARTNER. See Assign Business Partners to Company Codes and Business Partner (A2X) ‚Äì OData API for more insights.

Answer to question 2 on the recommended approach:

Generally, it is recommended to used released APIs (A2X) for your master data and any document payload you want to enrich, for example Company Code and Address services, BP where you deem necessary.

 

Regarding Belgian e-invocing in public cloud, these Blogs provides some valuable insights:

Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario

Electronic Invoicing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Material availability date is considering the Avg Ins...
entry.content:
• GRPT: Time needed by the warehouse team to move material from GR to stock.
  • AID: Time needed for quality inspection before the material is released to unrestricted stock.
  • System logic: When both are maintained, the system takes the longer of the two as the controlling factor for MAD.
    • If AID > GRPT ‚Üí Inspection time dominates.
    • If GRPT > AID ‚Üí Warehouse processing dominates.

That‚Äôs why in your first case (GRPT=2, AID=3), MAD is pushed out by 3 days (inspection). In the second case (GRPT=3, AID=2), MAD is pushed out by 3 days (warehouse).

Yes, this can delay production if inspection takes longer than warehouse processing, because the material is not available until inspection is complete. The system is designed this way to ensure that only usable stock is considered available.

In short, the system always prioritizes whichever duration is longer (GRPT vs. AID). If you want warehouse time to be considered, set GRPT higher than AID. If inspection dominates, AID will control MAD. Businesses usually model whichever is the true bottleneck.

entry.title: More Effective Security Programs Through Security Risk Quantification
entry.content:
By Josh Marker, Head of Security Risk Management,  and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

 

Security Risks, Enterprise Risks, and Business Priorities

This year has seen a further rise in cyber threats with increasing business impact. Just in recent months, cyber attacks have disrupted retail chains, air travel and beer production, and an entire supply chain in the automotive industry requiring government support. Managing security risks well is more critical than ever to organizations.

From our conversations with customers and partners, we know that business leaders are concerned about security and compliance risks. We also know that many security leaders still struggle to communicate security risks, and, given the current climate, face challenges to justify investment when organizations are looking to cut cost and run more efficiently. Both sides are familiar and comfortable with uncertainty and balancing their respective risks. Business leaders set out strategic directions they bet the success of the company on, by opening new markets, launching new product lines, or investing in new technologies where despite good execution external factors outside of their control may determine the outcome. Security leaders similarly chart out strategies and uplift programs they anticipate will best defend their organizations against unpredictable and ever evolving threats. The remaining challenge to action appears to be miscommunication and misalignment.

For effective communication and decision on the appropriate response, we need to translate security risks into business terms, and in ways that they can be related and prioritized alongside enterprise risks and business priorities. At SAP, we have found that a quantitative security risk approach, based on the methodology of the FAIR Institute, is very helpful in providing that, as well as hold the organization to account driving change and effective progress through measurable accountability.

 

Risk Identification, Analysis and Response

Every risk analysis involves some combination of probability x impact. The problem is that calculating either is very difficult. There is in cybersecurity in general a lack of good data, but organizations struggle even more to estimate to probability of a particular event to occur in their own landscape ‚Äì especially if a new threat hasn‚Äôt happened yet. Impact is similarly difficult to estimate, as that depends in large part on the intent and actions of the adversary. This forces you to shoehorn more likely but lower impact events together with low probability but catastrophic potential outcomes.

The common ‚Äúrainbow‚Äù risk matrix is a poor communicator for this. Even when category ranges are appropriately chosen, and position of the risk on the matrix is justified, it gives an inappropriately definite and reductive answer that allows risks to both be under- and overrated. It doesn‚Äôt tell the whole story and therefore is often not a useful communication device to convince others ‚Äì especially those outside cybersecurity and business leaders - investment or action is required.

Risk Identification and Analysis with a Quantitative Approach

To better express this larger story, we need an approach that expresses risk in financial terms. It also needs to allow for uncertainty in the world. And it should account for inputs that are sometimes educated guesses.

In SAP, during risk identification, we try to capture as many parameters as possible for which we can reasonably find information or can make informed guesses on based on threat intelligence data and landscape scans of the likelihood the threat materializes in a given year. Subject matter experts (SMEs) provide the information, when can be expressed in a range ‚Äì avoiding the conversation falling in ‚Äúit depends‚Äù traps.

‚ÄúDefenders have to be right all the time, attackers only once‚Äù, is a common theme in cybersecurity. The reality is that attackers usually require multiple steps to succeed before they reach any data and system with high business impact, giving defenders multiple opportunities to put obstacles in their way, or detect and contain them. Attackers can be extremely lucky, by obtaining credentials of exactly the right privileged administrator, but more likely they follow a longer path of initial access, persistence, privilege escalation and lateral movement. By allowing the domain experts to express a range of scenarios and consequences for these parameters, supported by data available, we get a far more nuanced understanding of the risk.

Core input for impact is based on direct financial loss in case the risk materializes, to keep the financial calculation conservative and avoid exaggerating a risk. It‚Äôs always easier to present your case when able to say other less tangible downstream consequences are not included in the analysis, and the impact could be higher.

To make sense of the data ranges in the parameters, we use machine learning and run 50,000 Monte Carlo simulations to create a model for the risk scenario. This results in a dataset that is sorted by probability and impact and plotted on a graph. A curve is drawn through the data points, resulting in the Loss Exceedance Curve. This curve and the analysis that led to that is reviewed with the SMEs to validate if they agree and accept the results.

By following the curve from the top left to the bottom right, we can see what loss we can expect with what probability. In this example, the curve starts with a steep slope, indicating that a certain percentage of cases where the risk is manifested the impact is low. After that, the curve flattens out and ends with a long tail indicating rare but catastrophic cases. The way to read this is to find a probability along the vertical axis, for example 5%, then trace a horizontal line from that value until it intersects with the Loss Exceedance Curve. Follow a vertical line down from that intersection point to find the value along the horizontal axis, so in this case there is a 5% chance to exceed $126.4M in loss (in any given year, from this scenario). An average and 90th percentile financial impact is provided as an easy to remember label used in conversations, but always with the understanding of the curve behind it.

By updating the values of model parameters, we can express how planned remediations effect the financial risk by running the same Monte Carlo simulations to produce a Loss Exceedance Curve for the risk after remediations. That provides a projection of risk reduction for any investment or effort required. The model for the risk can also be rerun when new information emerges ‚Äì internally or externally ‚Äì that requires updating the parameters.

 

Loss Exceedance Curve as Communication Device

The Loss Exceedance Curve is very useful for security leaders to better understand their organization‚Äôs security risks, and how proposed remediations reduce that risk and what risk remains after any mitigations have been deployed and operationalized. This can be a sobering exercise if the investment to remediate is too close to the risk and projected risk reduction, forcing you to reevaluate your approach. On the other hand, it can also provide strong justification for that investment if it is only a fraction of the risk and risk reduction that would deliver.

But it works also well with business- and executive leaders. The narrative can be entirely expressed in likelihood and impact in financial terms, while avoiding complexity. The conversation takes place without cyber security jargon, aside from terms business leaders are bound to be familiar with from business reports, such as ransomware attacks and social engineering. It allows business leaders to evaluate security risks better and decide what scenarios they want to protect against and whether they consider the needed effort or investment justified. At times, even a small probability of a catastrophic outcome can lead to a business decision to address a low average risk threat. In other cases, the same business leaders can be more comfortable to accept a reasonable residual risk at a higher probability. Meanwhile, there is no need to go into technical details and explain how such threats would materialize that could derail the discussion, unless a business leader specifically requests it.

When business leaders challenge the impact parameters, the model can be adjusted with more accurate information and the simulations rerun. Since business leaders typically own risks ‚Äì security or enterprise ‚Äì it is just as important that they stand behind the inputs into the model as the security and compliance SMEs. The balance between risk reduction and remediation cost along the curve further helps justification for investment of financial and human resources. If most of the risk can be addressed with a minor investment, this can set the upper limit of what is feasible. On the other hand, the long tail of the curve can justify a greater investment to limit the likelihood and impact of catastrophic events.

Allowing both sides to debate the risk through the Loss Exceedance Curve and follow its slope, it serves as an excellent communication device. It helps security and business leaders to get on the same page and express complex scenarios in a way both can understand and relate to.

 

Investment Prioritization and Optimization

The quantification of security risks enables prioritization among them and see where there may be overlaps in mitigation strategies. The remediation plan for one risk is likely to have positive impact on other risks in a layered defense approach. For instance, stronger automated network controls are likely to have a positive impact on the reachability of known vulnerabilities, beyond their immediate intent to protect the network. Such remediations should be prioritized.

Other risks can prove not to have much business impact at all in relation to others. Security professionals and business leaders are prone to overreaction when certain threats hit the media ‚Äì whether through security conferences or business press ‚Äì and overvalue the importance of a threat. Risk quantification assists in prioritizing what is important and avoids chasing ghosts while greater immediate risks remain. This way, constrained budgets can be optimized for greater effectiveness in risk reduction.

 

Security Program Governance

The effects are even greater when the risk analysis and response tracking are tied to data than indicates progress along the remediation plan. For instance, the percentage compliance of the landscape with security policies, or how well a team meets remediation target timelines for alerts from landscape scans, or how fast a team adopts a central service can be directly tied to model parameters. That way the model can be rerun with updated parameters as remediation plans progress to show how much risk has been reduced for the effort and how well the organization is progressing on the planned timeline.

The Loss Exceedance Curve aids in target setting, as well. It protects us against unrealistic expectations of targets that can‚Äôt be achieved or require high effort to squeeze out a bit more risk reduction. At the same time, it prevents organizations from setting targets too low, because it believes that is what the available resources can achieve. The Loss Exceedance Curve shows at what percentage of remediation of the threat the residual risk falls to an acceptable level. That level is the target to achieve.

 

Summary

The Loss Exceedance Curve helps express the uncertainty that we find in the world: ranges of values are used for inputs which means that variations in outputs need to be expressed. The Loss Exceedance Curve helps us do that, enabling better conversations among various stakeholders, including SMEs who live and breathe the cyber jargon, as well as the managers and business leaders who make decisions that govern and guide the organization.

This approach leads to truly risk-informed decisions and prioritization, rather than what feels good, what cyber textbooks tell us, what vendors sell, or what was exciting at the latest security conference.

 

More Information

For more information, please see:

  • Which UK retailers have been hit by cyber attacks in 2025?
  • EU agency confirms ransomware attack behind airport disruptions
  • Brewer Asahi suspends domestic operations after cyberattack disrupts ordering and shipping
  • Government to guarantee ¬£1.5bn JLR loan after cyber shutdown
  • FAIR Institute

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series : My Terrace Garden
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Sumaiya, and I joined SAP in 2015 as a Scholar and since then have worked in different areas and roles.

Today, I‚Äôd love to share a little about my hobby as part of the SAP Community Hobbies series üå±

What began as a simple interest is now a green space with over 300 plants, including fruit plants, vegetables, ornamental plants, succulents, and cactus. It is my space to slow down, reconnect, and find joy beyond screens and schedules.

Aerial view of my terrace garden

 Once an empty wall, now a layered story of vines, foliage, and flowers growing together.

Succulent Mini garden

 

 

How and when did I start this hobby?

During the COVID period, when we were home most of the time, that old familiarity returned. My husband and I started with just a few plants on our terrace‚Äînothing ambitious. But slowly, one plant became many. Caring for them became part of our daily life, bringing calm, purpose, and continuity in an uncertain time.

Looking back, gardening taught me patience long before I recognized it as a lesson. You cannot rush a seedling or force a fruit to ripen‚Äîit grows in its own time, as long as you show up consistently.

Started with Few Palm plants and Jasmine

 

What does my garden look like today?

Our home garden includes fruit plants like pomegranate, chickoo, mango, rose apple, sweet lime, star fruit, mulberry, figs, guava and lemon;

vegetable plants such as curry leaves, Drumstick, chillies, beans, tapioca, sweet potato, coriander;

along with ornamental plants, succulents, and cactus.

We may get just 3‚Äì4 mangoes in a season, but the joy has never been about the numbers.

Sapodilla, Figs, Green Pepper (Which post drying in sunlight is used as Black Pepper)

 

French Beans, Mangoes, Pomegranate, Rose Apple and Drumstick (Moringa Plant)

The Bright Colors in the green garden

 

What do I love most about it?

The biggest reward is the experience.

Seeing a plant every day, watching it grow slowly, noticing the first bud, and waiting eagerly for it to ripen‚Äîit creates a kind of happiness that‚Äôs hard to explain. When your own plant finally bears fruit, it feels like a quiet celebration.

I truly enjoy showing my plants to others. Sharing that space gives me deep, immense happiness and a sense of gratitude for small, everyday wins.

Colorful Blooms that makes the day even brighter

 

Challenges and how I deal with them

Gardening isn‚Äôt always easy. Some plants don‚Äôt survive. Some seasons don‚Äôt cooperate. And because our plants are on an open terrace, weeds have been one of the biggest challenges. Most weekends are spent patiently removing them, making sure they don‚Äôt overpower the plants we‚Äôve worked so hard to nurture.

Another persistent challenge is mealy bugs‚Äîthey require constant attention and effort to control. Since we strongly believe in keeping our garden as natural as possible, we avoid chemical solutions. Instead, we rely on organic remedies, using neem oil and turmeric, which may take more time but align with how we want to care for our plants.

Each challenge has taught me to observe more closely, adapt quickly, and accept that not everything is within my control. Every setback becomes a lesson‚Äîfor the next plant, the next season.

A proud moment

My proud moments are not big milestones. They are simple, quiet ones:

the first fruit on a plant I nurtured from the beginning,

a plant that survived when I truly thought it wouldn‚Äôt,

and a harvest that felt earned, not measured.

One plant I will always remember is a snake plant I gifted myself on my birthday during the lockdown. It arrived in a tiny 3‚Äì4 inch pot. As it grew, I repotted it into a larger one, and soon I noticed new plants appearing around it. I separated them into individual pots‚Äîand the cycle kept repeating. Today, I have over 30‚Äì40 snake plants, and I can no longer tell which one was the very first. Somehow, that makes me smile even more.

Propagating from one single snake plant into so many that covered my walking passage, truly this plant amazes me!

 

As our plants grew, they also became homes for life beyond us. We‚Äôve had bulbul birds visit our terrace frequently, building nests among the plants. Over the past two years, they built nests three times and laid eggs. Watching those eggs hatch and seeing tiny baby birds grow was incredibly heartwarming‚Äîit felt like our garden had become a safe space not just for plants, but for living beings too.

BulBul Birds looking for a spot to make a nest

 

 

Bulbul bird nest with 2 eggs hatched

 

More recently, we noticed birds slowly discovering our garden. We began placing bird food, and with time, the number of visitors kept increasing. One evening, we heard the most beautiful chorus of birds and stepped out onto the terrace to witness a magical sight‚Äîover 20 Munia birds gathered together, calmly enjoying the space. It was a moment of pure joy and gratitude.

Bird Food we placed thinking Bulbul birds will stay in terrace permanently, but something different happened. Looks like this bird food, Munia bird likes more

 

What makes me most proud is seeing this love for plants extend beyond me. My kids often join us while watering the plants, and my 7-year-old daughter especially looks forward to fruit-harvesting days‚Äîthose moments turn the garden into shared joy and lasting memories.

These experiences remind me that when you show up consistently and care deeply, growth happens‚Äîsometimes quietly, sometimes in ways you never expected.

Tools and resources for beginners  and Tips for getting started

If you are completely new to gardening and worried about plants dying, I always recommend starting simple and stress-free.

A great place to begin is with succulents, especially Mother of Millions. Succulents are incredibly forgiving. You can pluck just one leaf, and it will grow into a new plant. With Mother of Millions, it‚Äôs even more fascinating‚Äîa single leaf can grow into 10‚Äì15 new plants. It requires very little care: moist soil and watering on alternate days, or even once every 2‚Äì3 days, works just fine.

Plant : Mother Of Millions

 

Another easy and joyful way to start is by regrowing vegetables in water. Take a small portion of used vegetables, place it in a bottle or container with water, and keep it in indirect sunlight. You‚Äôll be surprised at how quickly new growth appears. A small piece of ginger or sweet potato can grow into a healthy plant with fresh leaves. Even a partly used onion placed in water can turn into fresh spring onions‚Äîperfect for a quick salad.

In the Kitchen when i see even a small possibility that the vegetables are sprouting, then instead of cooking them, i put in water bottle to help it grow and then repot in some pot and this cycle repeats

 

Many plants don‚Äôt even need soil to begin with. Simply place them in a bottle of water and change the water once a week. It‚Äôs minimal effort with maximum joy.

Easiest way to grow plans with minimum effort.

 

You don‚Äôt need a big space or expensive tools to start gardening. All it really takes is curiosity, patience, and a little care‚Äîand the confidence grows along with the plants üå±

How I keep improving

Over the years, I‚Äôve learned that not every plant needs the same kind of care. Some grow easily with minimal effort, while others demand time, attention, and patience. Understanding this difference has been one of the most valuable lessons gardening has taught me.

With time, confidence grows‚Äîand so does curiosity. I‚Äôve become more comfortable trying new plants and new challenges, learning through experience rather than perfection. Each season adds a little more awareness, a little more patience.

Growth doesn‚Äôt always need rigid structure. Sometimes, it simply needs time, consistency, and care.

 

The connection to the SAP world

The connection is stronger than it appears.

Gardening is about systems thinking‚Äîunderstanding dependencies like soil, water, sunlight, and timing. You can‚Äôt optimize one part and ignore the rest.

In SAP projects, we build solutions that must be sustainable, balanced, and human-centric. Gardening reminds me that real success comes from nurturing systems patiently, not forcing outcomes.

It helps me show up at work more grounded, focused, and calm.

 

 

What‚Äôs next? There‚Äôs no finish line here‚Äîjust more learning, more plants, and more quiet joy. I look forward to continuing this journey, one leaf, one flower, and one fruit at a time.

Thank you for reading. If gardening resonates with you‚Äîor if you‚Äôre curious about how to start, what to grow, or how to nurture plants at home‚ÄîI‚Äôd be happy to connect and have a chat üåø

And if you have a hobby that helps you slow down, disconnect, or think better, I‚Äôd love to hear about it.

entry.title: Re: VS Code Fiori Generator - Authentication failed: Unable to access any service catalogs
entry.content:
Some of my SAP user password characters were not supported.

Rt¬∏L¬∂√îg%v√≥√∑V)#√ìg√ù3√§√ú

I have investigated which ones are supported, and which ones are not:

  • These characters are NOT supported: roman characters with accents and symbols outside US-ASCII like √î√≥√∑√ì√ù√§√ú etc.
  • These characters are supported: A to Z, a to z, 0 to 9 and ALL characters which are part of US-ASCII: !"#$%&'()*+,-./:;<=>?@[\]^_`{|}~

For information:

  1. This article says that with S/4HANA ON-PREMISE, SAP Fiori tools running in VS Code support only the authentication type "Basic authentication".
  2. This article says that the HTTP basic authentication supports user names and passwords containing only US-ASCII characters (with reference to the note 1240796 - HTTP logon with Basic Authorization or special character; this note was posted in 2008 and not updated, but maybe it's still valid).
  3. This article and RFC7617 (September 2015) say that the HTTP Basic Authentication can support the transport of user names and passwords via ¬´ the charset auth-param ¬ª whose ¬´ only allowed value is "UTF-8" ¬ª i.e. characters not limited to US-ASCII.
  4. I'll open a ticket with SAP Support.

Thanks @amontella96 and @Joery .

entry.title: Re: BADI MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA doesn't get triggered dur...
entry.content:
Hello @taufikkasim 

Thank you for your question

The MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA is specific for MIGO and GR scenarios. Hence why it does not trigger the desired action in your scenario. So, your custom fields exists in FDP_GR4PO_COL_SLIP_SRV extension but the system does not execute enhancement spot in the SES driven posting step that fills the document, which is why it stays blank. It is a limited pattern for MMIM BAdIs and this is explained in KBA 2956742. You can also read App Extensibility: Post Goods Movement for more details.

On your question about a BAdI you can use for SES scenario, it is important to note that the public cloud extensibility does not generally provide alternative BAdI that lets you populate those Goods Movement slip data source custom fields during the SES approval created material document step.

Considering the public cloud emphasises on keeping the core clean, I suggest you:

  1. Use only fields that are already available and filled in your data source. Basically, saying you should extend the same data source and use the available underlying fields and not create new ones in posting. See KBA 3673885 for more details.
  2. Change your process so that you post GR through a GR app that supports MMIM BAdIs. Basically, saying you should avoid posting automatically through SES. This will allow your current approach with MMIM BAdIs to execute reliably. See KBA 2956742 and App Extensibility: Post Goods Movement for more insights.
  3. If your requirement is purely to enrich printing, consider using output time enrichment where you can. You can use output time for example to fill custom fields when processing your output rather than during document creation. See KBA 3008187 and  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/47845e7df8f14ecfaf34079d229f031f.html for more details.

To summarise:

  • HU or backend BAdI is not the issue here.
  • The root cause is process context. The GR slip is printed for a material document that is created from SES approval, while your MMIM_ITEM_PROVIDE_DATA BAdI is only executed for supported GR apps, not this background SES posting.
  • Public cloud strongly suggests staying within available fields in FDP_GR4PO_COL_SLIP_SRV, change process to a GR app that triggers MMIM enhancements.

Best regards

Chris

"cds": {

entry.title: SAP Practice and Certification Journey
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-evolving logistics industry, digital transformation and integrated systems play a critical role in ensuring efficiency, transparency, and sustainability. As someone who has received formal education in logistics and is actively continuing my professional development in this field, I strongly believe that learning SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management (TM) is a natural and strategic step in my career journey.

My motivation to learn SAP stems from my desire to deepen my understanding of logistics beyond operational processes and into system-driven decision making. Transportation Management is one of the core pillars of supply chain operations, and SAP S/4HANA TM provides an end-to-end perspective‚Äîfrom planning and execution to cost settlement and performance analysis. Gaining hands-on practice with this system will allow me to better understand how logistics processes are designed, optimized, and managed within global organizations.

Additionally, learning SAP S/4HANA TM will help me develop a more analytical and structured mindset. Exposure to different ERP systems not only enhances technical competence but also enables logistics professionals to think holistically, connecting operations, finance, and strategy. I believe this knowledge will significantly contribute to my ability to analyze complex logistics scenarios and propose effective, data-driven solutions.

Through SAP Practice and Certification, my goal is to strengthen my professional skill set, bridge the gap between theory and real-world applications, and position myself as a more capable and future-ready logistics profession

entry.title: Re: Password deactivation through BAPI_USER_CHANGE
entry.content:
Hi,

 

for deactivating a password it is allowed exceptionally, to set LOGONDATA_CODVN and LOGONDATAX_CODVN to the value X. You need to leave all other password related fields as they are, to avoid error messages.

This exception is documented in SAP note #780485 .

 

b.rgds, Bernhard

entry.title: Re: Best Practice for Adjusting Project Progress Percenta...
entry.content:
Hello @Minsung_Lee 

Thank you for your question. See my response on each.

My Questions:

1. Is adjusting Plan values the correct approach for mid-project progress reconciliation, or should I be using ETC adjustments instead?

Answer: No. You should use ETC adjustments, not plan manipulation in this scenario. The standard process is a monthly review where you review your PoC and adjust the estimate to complete in the Review Customer Projects app. See Analyzing the Process Steps for Customer Project Management for more details.

2. What is the SAP-recommended standard practice for ongoing progress alignment when external progress differs from system-calculated PoC?

Answer: Revenue recognition that is event based derives cost based on PoC and it uses planned cost, actuals and your forecast values, so changing to plan just to force a percent will distort the finance logic. See Customer Projects with Event-Based Revenue Recognition.

3. Should I be using forecast month settings systematically throughout the project lifecycle rather than only at project closure?

Answer: Yes, you should use Forecast Month because, the apps evaluate KPIs and checks the deviation up to the month you forecasted for and the system determines ETC/EAC while it considers your deviations from adjustments you made in preceding periods. See KBA 3617498, Transfer Project Forecast to Finance and Review Customer Projects for more guidance.

Also, this document provides application job specifically to set the forecast month for customer projects. https://help.sap.com/doc/7c9e0bbbd1664c2581b2038a1c7ae4b3/2602.500/en-US/FSD_CE2602.pdf

I recommend you stick to the standard practice:

  1. Set Forecast Month monthly for projects.
  2. Review Customer Projects, align your process by adjusting ETC and not by changing plan.
  3. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?
  4. Use Transfer Project Forecast to Finance to keep forecast and feed your finance.
  5. Run Event Based Revenue Recognition as per your closing cycle to post revenue based on your latest PoC and forecasts

4. What are the risks or downstream impacts of frequently modifying Plan values vs. ETC values?

Answer:

If you frequently modify your Plan values,

  • you risk blurring the meaning of plan versus baseline, budget and variance.
  • You can create misleading cost based PoC and your revenue recognitions results because plan is an input to PoC. See Customer Projects with Event-Based Revenue Recognition

Should you adjust ECT values

  • You keep plan as a planning baseline and use ETC as your operational forecast lever.
  • The system expects ETC adjustments to ensure your forecast deviations are handled across the periods. See Transfer Project Forecast to Finance and Review Customer Projects for more guidance.

Question 5 is answered with the provided references.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Happy New Year and Happy Coding of AI Agents!
entry.content:
I hope everyone found their way into the new year and had some peaceful time over the holidays! Being back at work, I started to try out all the cool announcements from last year. One of them is LiteLLM, where SAP contributed to function as an official LLM provider. That means you can now build AI Agents with the LiteLLM gateway and all the AI Agent frameworks that are compatible and provide your Generative AI Hub credentials to connect to LLMs via SAP's AI Foundation.

I tried out CrewAI first because it is such a powerful and widely used framework and I have been curious and willing to try it out for some time now!

First things first: What is LiteLLM?

LiteLLM is a library that provides a unified, provider-agnostic API for calling large language models (LLMs) and handling common tasks (completion, chat, streaming, multimodal inputs). It standardizes request/response handling and includes utilities that speed up integration with agent frameworks and tooling. Essentially it is a gateway between LLM providers and AI Agent frameworks.

That means you can use your Generative AI Hub credentials to build state of the art AI Agents with any of the models available through GenAI Hub and any of the AI Agent frameworks compatible with LiteLLM. This combination is extremely powerful because that means you can use LLMs hosted or managed by SAP (Mistral, Llama, Nvidia) and models from our partners such as Azure OpenAI, Amazon Bedrock (including Anthropic) and Gemini.

üëâcheck all the available models here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3437766

üëâAnd all the AI Agent frameworks including: CrewAI, LangGraph, PydanticAI, Google ADK, Strands SDK, OpenAI ADK, LlamaIndex, Microsoft Agents and many more. You can find a list with examples here: http://sap-contributions.github.io/litellm-agentic-examples/

How to get started

Now to get started you need an SAP AI Core instance with the extended plan (on SAP BTP), that means you have access to Generative AI Hub and all the LLMs available.

SAP BTP Cockpit, Instances and Subscriptions, SAP AI Core ‚Äì extended plan

LiteLLM is directing calls to the LLMs through the orchestration service on Generative AI Hub. That means you do not need to deploy your models on SAP AI Core. You only need the out of the box deployment of the orchestration service. This way you can easily switch between all the models available via the orchestration service.

Screenshot from Model Library of SAP AI Launchpad showing models available via Orchestration Service.

 On a side note: you do not need SAP AI Launchpad as the UI to do any of this. You can also find your endpoints via API calls (more info: developer tutorial or documentation). or use the SAP Cloud SDK for AI.

Build your crew of agents

Now you only need to install Python. Once that is done you need to install the LiteLLM library and in my case also CrewAI:

pip install litellm crewai

Ok now we can actually start with building our AI Agent with CrewAI. As the name suggests you build a crew of agents that have a set of tools available to accomplish certain tasks. CrewAI uses tasks to bridge the gap between high-level goals and concrete agent actions, assigning specific objectives and expected outputs.

Agents

CrewAI recommends storing your agent configuration in and agents.yaml file. Important are the parameters: role, goal, backstory and llm. The parameter llm defines which LLM provider you want to use. We want to use SAP as the provider and GPT-4o as the model (provider/model -> sap/gpt-4o). As already described above you can use any model here that is available via the orchestration service. {payload} is a variable that will be filled during runtime.

theft_crime_scene_investigator:
  role: >
    Theft Crime Scene Investigator
  goal: >
    Predict the missing values of stolen items using the SAP-RPT-1 model via the call_rpt1 tool use this payload {payload} as input.
  backstory: >
    An expert theft crime investigator specialised on predicting the value of stolen luxury goods.
  llm: sap/gpt-4o

Tasks

In the tasks.yaml you define the name of the task, the description, the expected output and which agent can do this task. {payload} is again the variable that will be filled during runtime.

inspection_task:
  description: >
    Analyze the theft crime scene and predict the missing values of stolen items using the SAP-RPT-1 model via the call_rpt1 tool. 
    Use this dict {payload} as input.
  expected_output: >
    JSON with predicted values for the stolen items.
  agent: theft_crime_scene_investigator

Tools

You can also define custom tools in Python and hand them over to your agents to use. The following tool for example gives the model access to the SAP-RPT-1 model (try it out here: rpt.cloud.sap).

from rpt1.call_rpt1 import RPT1Client

rpt1_client = RPT1Client()

@tool("call_rpt1")
def call_rpt1(payload: dict) -> str:
    """Function to call RPT-1 model via RPT1Client"""
    response = rpt1_client.post_request(json_payload=payload)
    if response.status_code == 200:
        return response.json()
    else:
        return f"Error: {response.status_code} - {response.text}"

If you want to know more about how to make the request to SAP-RPT-1 check out this code.

Building the Crew

You might wonder how this all comes together? Now you plug all those pieces together and build your crew. The crew needs at least one agent, but can have more, any tools you want the agent to use, you can also assign here. And each agent has at least one task.

from crewai import Agent, Crew, Task, Process
from crewai.project import CrewBase, agent, task, crew, tool

@CrewBase
class MurderMystery():
    """MurderMystery crew"""

    agents_config = "config/agents.yaml"
    tasks_config = 'config/tasks.yaml'

    
    def theft_crime_scene_investigator(self) -> Agent:
        return Agent(
            config=self.agents_config['theft_crime_scene_investigator'], 
            verbose=True,
            tools=[call_rpt1]
        )

    
    def inspection_task(self) -> Task:
        return Task(
            config=self.tasks_config['inspection_task'] # type: ignore[index]
        )

    @crew
    def crew(self) -> Crew:
        return Crew(
            agents=self.agents,  # Automatically collected by the  decorator
            tasks=self.tasks,    # Automatically collected by the  decorator.
            process=Process.sequential,
            verbose=True,
        )

Run the crew

murder_mystery = MurderMystery()
result = murder_mystery.crew().kickoff(inputs={'payload': payload})
print("\nüìò Result:\n", result)

 

Additional Infos

  • If you need any help in setting up your Python environment, check out the exercise 02 -Setup Python environment from my CodeJam.
  • Full code here: https://github.com/noravth/agentic-ai-codejam-collection
  • Documentation SAP and LiteLLM 

Happy Coding and feel free to reach out anytime!

entry.title: Re: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
HI David,

in the cube we have:

key _CurrencyField.CurrencyField as CurrencyField,

//Currency

cast( case $projection.CurrencyField

when 'CCC ' then CompanyCodeCurrency

when 'GC' then GlobalCurrency

when 'FC' then FunctionalCurrency

else null end as waers_curc preserving type ) as Currency,

 

//Amount in Display Currency

@Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'

cast( case $projection.CurrencyField

when 'CCC' then AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency

when 'GC' then AmountInGlobalCurrency

when 'FC' then AmountInFunctionalCurrency

else null end as farp_amount_display_crcy ) as AmountInDisplayCurrency,

 

@Aggregation.default: #SUM

@Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'

cast(( $projection.AmountInDisplayCurrency * -1 ) as fis_hsl_inverted) as InvertedAmountInDisplayCrcy,

 

In the query we then select restricted, e.g.:

@AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS

@AnalyticsDetails.query.elementHierarchy.parent: 'NetRevenueAmountInDspCrcy'

@Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'Currency'

@EndUserText.label : 'Sales Deduction'

@UI.textArrangement: #TEXT_LAST

cast( case when ( SemanticTag = 'SALES_DED' )

then ( InvertedAmountInDisplayCrcy )

else null end as fins_sales_deduction preserving type ) as SalesDeductionAmountInDspCrcy,

 

Best regards,

Roman

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA for Group Reporting - Using Automatic Posting Rules for Consolidation of Investments
entry.content:
Introduction

Automating postings in SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting dramatically reduces manual effort and increases accuracy in financial consolidation. With release 2508.3, you can define posting rules specifically for consolidation groups and automate group-level postings such as the consolidation of investments.

 

What's New for Consolidation Group Postings

Automatic posting rules (you can find more details in this introduction blog) for consolidation group postings now include the following features:

  • Group Structure Filters to select the units based on their assignment in the group structure.
  • Field assignment for Investee Unit to maintain investor-investee relationships in postings.
  • An enhanced log with a new tab to display the log items per investee unit and a quick link to display group structure assignment details.

 

Scenarios

Here are some typical examples of group postings that you can automate for the consolidation of investments:

  • First consolidation: elimination of investments, capital, retained earnings, other comprehensive income, and calculation of non-controlling interests (NCI)
  • Subsequent consolidation: NCI calculation for net income and other comprehensive income
  • Acquisitions and partial disposal of investments: elimination of changes in investments and adjustments for group share changes
  • Consolidation method changes: from/to purchase / equity method
  • Capital increases / decreases with no group share change
  • Total divestitures

Note: Other automatic postings, such as eliminations or reclassifications that must be posted at the consolidation group level can also be defined.

 

Rule Type: Postings for Consolidation Groups

Posting rules defined with the rule type Postings for Consolidation Groups can only be assigned, via the rule group, to tasks of category 55 - Automatic Postings for Consolidation Groups. These tasks are processed exclusively from the consolidation monitor.

Posting rules of this type include options tailored for group postings, as described below.

 

Defining Group Structure Filters

In a posting rule, a group structure filter selects units (consolidation units, partner units, investee units) based on their assignment in the current consolidation group defined in the Manage Group Structure app.

Example use cases:

  • Select only consolidation units with purchase method
  • Select only partner units with first consolidation in the current period
  • Select only consolidation units that change their method from equity to purchase

You define group structure filters in the Group Structure Filters tab of the Manage Rules for Automatic Postings app.

You define in the group structure filter how to select the units, using:

  • the consolidation method assigned to the unit (for example, parent, purchase, equity). 
  • the assignment stage of the unit for the current period (for example, first consolidation, subsequent consolidation, divestiture), including whether it applies at the beginning or end of the period.
  • the method changes (from/to) that occur for the consolidation unit in the current period, including whether the change happens at the beginning or end of the period.

The selection of consolidation method, assignment stage, and method change are optional.

For instance, you can select units considering only their method and not their assignment stage, or considering only their method change. However, assignment stages can only be selected when a consolidation method is specified.

Note: In addition to delivered consolidation methods (parent, purchase, equity), you can create your own consolidation methods in the self service configuration Define Consolidation Methods to support further scenarios, such as proportional consolidation or units held for sale.

 

Using Group Structure Filters in Posting Rules

In posting rules of the type Postings for Consolidation Groups, you can assign a group structure filter in the source data section to select consolidation units, partner units and investee units.

This filter is optional. If no filter is assigned, the rule selects all units assigned to the consolidation group.

Example:

A rule that eliminates investments during first consolidation might:

  • Filter consolidation units with a group structure filter PP (consolidation methods: parent, purchase), and
  • Filter partner units with a group structure filter PU_FC (consolidation method: purchase; assignment stage: first consolidation).

By combining the selection objects (for example, FS items, subitems) with the group structure filters (for example, consolidation methods, assignment stages, method changes) across consolidation units, partner units, and investee units in the posting rule definitions allows you to precisely target complex scenarios for automation.

 

Organizing Posting Rules

Automating group postings for consolidation of investments typically requires many rules. To keep them manageable:

  • Use nodes in the rule group to organize rules by method (purchase, equity, for example) and then by assignment stage (first consolidation, subsequent consolidation, investments changes, equity changes, divestiture, for example).

  • Adopt a naming convention that reflects method, assignment stage, and FS items to make the log easier to read and to present posting rules in a logical sequence (see the log example at the end of this blog).

 

Defining Posting Rules

When defining posting rules for the consolidation of investments, consider the aspects mentioned below.

Rounding difference

When defining rules that use variables with percentages (for example, group share, non controlling share), minor rounding differences can create imbalances. To clear this imbalance, add an extra posting line to balance the entry (see posting line #4 below).

Investee Unit

The investee unit field is typically inherited from the partner unit for investment FS items and from the consolidation unit for equity FS items.

This inheritance links investor and investee units for entries related to investment and equity changes.

In a first consolidation posting, this linkage allows the log to display source and posting lines from the investor (investment FS items) and investee (equity FS items) together, improving the understanding of the posting. (see the log example at the end of this blog).

It is therefore important, when defining the posting rule, to ensure that the investee unit field is not cleared. In most cases, it inherits its value from the source data, If needed, it can also be assigned directly in the rule from the consolidation or partner unit using the field assignment section with the Value Of option set to Consolidation Unit or Partner Unit.

 

Displaying the Log

The example below shows how the log can help analyze postings for consolidation of investments. It illustrates also the importance of the naming convention for the rules, and the role of the investee unit field. 

(1) The tab Investee Unit is selected so the investee units are displayed and can be selected in the left pane (2).

(2) The investee unit GDI US West is selected in the left pane. The log items for this investee unit are displayed on the right. They include the investment FS items from investors GDI Spain and GDI France, and equity FS items for the investee unit GDI US West.

The log items are grouped by rule.

The first 2 rules (investments and equity for first consolidation with purchase method) are expanded in this example.

(3) The investments in the investor units are eliminated against retained earnings in the investee unit. Since the investor GDI Spain is not held by 100%, non-controlling interests (NCI) are also posted here. 

(4) The equity in the investee unit is eliminated against the retained earnings, non controlling interests are calculated and posted.

(5) The group share % of the investors and investee unit are displayed as a variable.

When the Investee Units tab is selected, you can click the investee unit in the left pane to open its group structure assignment details:

Note: The examples provided in this blog are simplified to illustrate the features. Other configurations are possible.

More Information

  • Rules for Automatic Postings
  • How to Define Group Structure Filters 
  • Blog Introducing New Rules for Automatic Postings 

Special thanks to MareikeBaudewig for reviewing this blog!

entry.title: Sending JWE/JWS Encrypted JSON Payload from SAP PI/PO to Bank API
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We have a new requirement from one of our banking partners where payment data needs to be sent from SAP PI/PO to the Bank‚Äôs API in encrypted and signed JSON format using JWE/JWS standards.

Integration Scenario:

Source: SAP ECC (IDoc)
Existing Flow:  IDoc ‚Üí SAP PI/PO ‚Üí SOAP Call
Expected Flow: IDoc ‚Üí SAP PI/PO ‚Üí Encrypted JSON ‚Üí Bank Corporate API

Security Requirements (as provided by the Bank):

Encryption Mechanism: JWE
Key Encryption Algorithm: RSA-OAEP-256
Content Encryption Method: A256GCM
Signing Algorithm: RS256 (JWS)

Request for Feasibility

I would like to understand whether SAP PI/PO (7.5 single stack) can support JWE + JWS encryption/signing using:

Standard REST Adapter capabilities
Custom Adapter Module
Custom java mapping (UDF)
Or any SAP-recommended approach

If custom development is required, please advise:

Whether external libraries (e.g., Nimbus JOSE + JWT) can be deployed on PI/PO: If yes, then where can i get required JAR files.
Any limitations or performance considerations
Recommended best practices for implementing secure REST communication in PI/PO

Any insights, implementation steps, or past experience handling similar requirements would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Adobe forms: Header paragraph need to repeat every page

The reason it's not working is because the heading will only be repeated within the flowed content as a header if it's set as positioned (and marked as such under overflow of the flowed subform), but you have it set to flowed.  You do have the option of placing it in the master page as noted in the other replies but it is not required.

Ryan Crosby

entry.title: What‚Äôs New on My Metrics 2026 Q1 QRC: Schedule a Metrics Report
entry.content:
In my last blog post, I announced the release of scheduled Metrics Reports for 2026 Q1 QRC, and now it‚Äôs time to take a closer look at how they help you stay on top of your data.

Keeping an eye on performance metrics is essential but manually checking them can quickly become time-consuming. With scheduled Metrics Reports in My Metrics, you can stay informed without the extra effort. By subscribing to a metrics report, you‚Äôll automatically receive updates on changes in your selected metrics, delivered on a daily, weekly, or monthly schedule. Simply choose the recurrence pattern that works best for you and let the insights come to you right when you need them.

Below is a practical guide to what the feature does, how to set it up, common options, and tips for best results.

Why Subscribe to a Metrics Report?

Subscribing to a metrics report lets you receive regular, automated updates on metric changes without having to manually check stories. It ensures that teams and stakeholders get consistent snapshots of what has changed since the previous report, while giving you control over the delivery cadence and recipients, so insights arrive exactly when they‚Äôre most useful.

What You Need Before You Start 

  • Access to My Metrics and permission to create subscriptions (check your role settings).
  • If you want recurrence based on working days, you must have a working day calendar defined in the underlying model. For details, see Use a Working Day Calendar for Your Series.
  • Only metrics that come from tunnel connection type models are supported in the report (this connection allows controlled exposure of data outside the corporate network). For more information, see Live Data Connections to SAP S/4HANA.
  • This feature is only available in SAP Analytics Cloud tenants running in the Cloud Foundry environment (not available in the Neo environment).

Quick Step-by-Step Setup

  1. Open the metrics list you want to subscribe to in My Metrics.
  2. In list view, choose More (the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ / menu) and pick Subscribe to Metrics Report.
  3. In the creation dialog, enter a Subscription Name (mandatory) and a Description (recommended). Note: the name can contain only letters and numbers no special characters. 
  4. Click Next to choose the schedule.
  5. Define the recurrence pattern: Day, Week, or Month. If you use Working Day(s), pick the model that contains your working day calendar:
    • Day
      • Choose Day(s) or Working Day(s) and enter the frequency number (e.g., every 2 days).
      • If you choose Working Day(s), select the model and calendar to define non-working days
    • Week
      • Set the number of weeks between reports.
      • Choose one or more weekdays to run the report, or select Working Day and pick an ordinal working day (first, second, third, fourth, or last) from the calendar.
      • When using Working Day, select the appropriate model and calendar if more than one is available. 
    • Month
      • Day option: specify a day number (1‚Äì31). If the month has fewer days than the number you entered, the report runs on the month‚Äôs last day.
      • Working Day option: enter a frequency number or choose an ordinal working day (first, second, third, fourth, or last) of the month; select the model/calendar if required.
      • You can also schedule by ‚Äúnth weekday‚Äù (for example, the second Tuesday of each month).
      • Examples: entering -2 schedules the report for the second-to-last day of the month; entering 31 schedules it on the month‚Äôs last day. 
  6. Set the planned start date and time and when the recurrence should end (by end date or number of occurrences).
  7. Click Next and add at least one recipient in the Distribution List. You can select existing users or teams.
  8. Optionally uncheck ‚ÄúSend email notifications‚Äù if you prefer in-app notifications onlybelow an example of an email notification of a Metrics Report:                                                                                                 
  9. Save to create the subscription.

Other Important Details and Limitations

  • Each metrics report can include up to 15 metrics.
  • The report only includes metrics that have changed since their last recorded value, this focuses recipients on recent movement.
  • Sent reports are also accessible from in-app notifications.
  • If you set recurrence on working day calendars, no report is sent on non-working days defined by that calendar.

Manage subscriptions

Manage Subscriptions lets recipients control how they interact with a metrics report and lets owners copy, edit, or delete subscriptions. Recipients can copy a subscription or change their notification settings; only the subscription owner can edit or delete it. You can also preview subscription details from the Manage Subscriptions dialog. Note that you need the correct permissions to perform these actions.

Accessing and filtering subscriptions

  • Open the metrics list in My Metrics, then choose More ‚Üí Manage Subscriptions.
  • Use the filter to show Active Subscriptions (default) or switch to All Subscriptions to see inactive ones as well. This helps you quickly find the subscription you want to manage.

Copying a subscription

  • Select a subscription in the Manage Subscriptions dialog and choose Copy Subscription.
  • When you copy a subscription you duplicate its details but can change schedule or recipients. You become the owner of the new copy and it is independent of the original.

Modifying your notification settings

Recipients can mute or resume notifications for a subscription without affecting others. Steps:

  • Open the subscription, choose Notification Settings, then pick:
    • Resume Notifications
    • Mute Until: select a date and time to pause notifications until then
    • Mute All Scheduled Reports
  • Save changes. Your choices apply only to your account and won‚Äôt change other recipients‚Äô settings.

Editing a subscription (owner only)

Owners can edit name, description, schedule, and distribution list. Steps:

  • Open Manage Subscriptions, select the subscription, choose Edit Subscription, make changes, and save.
  • Note: changing a subscription may trigger a new report schedule; recipients will be affected by edits.

Deleting a subscription (owner only)

  • Owners can delete one or more subscriptions from the Manage Subscriptions dialog.
  • Deletion removes all recipients and cancels scheduled reports. Confirm deletion in the warning dialog to proceed.

Previewing subscription details

  • In Manage Subscriptions, select a subscription to view its details (description, schedule, end date, owner, distribution list).
  • Use Preview to verify settings before copying, editing, or deleting.

Best Practices

Use descriptive subscription names in the Description field to clearly communicate the purpose and intended audience, since the subscription name itself supports only alphanumeric characters. Before rolling it out broadly, test the subscription with a small group of recipients to validate the timing and content. If your reports depend on working days, make sure the model‚Äôs working day calendar is correctly configured and that the appropriate calendar is selected when multiple options are available. Finally, choose notification channels thoughtfully, use in-app notifications for teams working primarily in SAC, and enable email notifications for external stakeholders or wider visibility.

You can quickly find and act on the correct subscriptions by using filters, making it easier to manage them efficiently. If you need similar reports, you can copy an existing subscription without changing the original setup. Notifications can be muted temporarily when a report is sent too frequently and resumed later as needed. To prevent confusion, owners should clearly communicate any edits or deletions to recipients. If management options are not visible, it‚Äôs important to verify permissions, as available actions depend on assigned roles.

Troubleshooting Tips

  • If recipients don‚Äôt receive reports, confirm you‚Äôre on a Cloud Foundry tenant and that recipients‚Äô email addresses or user accounts are correct.
  • If a metric you expect is missing, check that it‚Äôs based on a tunnel connection type model and that it changed since the last report.
  • If the schedule doesn‚Äôt behave as expected with working days, review the model‚Äôs working day calendar and the selected calendar if multiple calendars are maintained.
  • If you can‚Äôt edit or delete a subscription, confirm you are the owner and have the required role.
  • If notifications don‚Äôt change after updating settings, re-open Manage Subscriptions to confirm your saved preferences.
  • If recipients stop receiving reports after edits, check the distribution list and schedule settings.

Wrapping Up

Subscribing to a metrics report in My Metrics is a simple way to keep stakeholders informed about metric changes with flexible scheduling and notification options. With attention to the working day settings and model selection, you can align report delivery to business calendars and avoid unnecessary messages on non-working days.

entry.title: Using SuccessFactors Onboarding for Country Transfers Without Recruiting
entry.content:
In this article, we discuss how employees who are moving to a legal entity in another country can be onboarded using SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, without SuccessFactors Recruiting.

The scenario covered here is a country transfer, not a global assignment. The employee‚Äôs employment in the source country ends, and a new employment is created in the target country.

Scenario Description

  • Current country: India
  • Target country: United States
  • Movement type: Country Transfer (not Global Assignment)
  • SuccessFactors Recruiting: Not used
  • Identity Authentication Service (IAS): Enabled
  • Onboarding module: Used for New Hire / Rehire

In this scenario, the employee will be treated as a new hire in the USA, while their employment in India is terminated.

Before we look at this process let us reconfirm the process with SuccessFactors Recruiting.

When onboarding is initiated from SuccessFactors Recruiting, the first ‚ÄòRehire Check‚Äô is initiated, this will trigger an employment profile selection check for the rehire co-ordinators.

They will only be able to confirm ‚ÄòRehire on New Employment‚Äô if the current ‚ÄòIndia‚Äô record has a termination date that is before the hire date on the new ‚ÄòUSA‚Äô employment.    

Once they confirm ‚ÄòRehire with New Employment‚Äô an email is sent to the employee asking them to complete the onboarding process using the employment profile switcher in the top right corner as shown below.

If the employee has not applied for a role in SuccessFactors Recruiting, and SuccessFactors Recruiting is enabled, it is best practice to quickly create a requisition and add the employee to it so that the process is initiated as above.

If you do not have SuccessFactors Recruiting, then the following is a process that can be used.

The first rehire check is only initiated from SuccessFactors Recruiting, it will not trigger from ‚ÄòAdd a new hire to onboarding‚Äô, this is on the roadmap but does not have a delivery date.

Step 1 ‚Äì Initiate onboarding using ‚ÄòAdd New Hire to Onboarding‚Äô

It is imperative that the email that is used is the personal email address and not the business email address.  The reason for this is the business email address is active in IAS.  You can use ‚Äòbusiness rules‚Äô in onboarding to send out a specific welcome email for ‚ÄòCountry Transfers‚Äô.

Dear XX

As we start your transfer we would like you to complete some basic information, once we have this we can use this data to allow you to finalize your transfer in SuccessFactors‚Ä¶..

Step 2 ‚Äì Employee receives IAS email

Employee receives the IAS email to their personal email address and completes Personal Data Collection.

Step 3 ‚Äì Rehire re-verification is triggered  

The second rehire verification is triggered.  The rehire co-ordinators can confirm a Rehire if there is a termination date on the India employment that is before the hire date of the USA employment.

Without termination date

With termination date

Step 4 ‚Äì Legal Entity Transfer email is sent

Once the rehire is accepted the onboarding system sends the ‚Äòlegal entity transfer‚Äô email to the business email address.  The system allows the employee to finish the onboarding process using the ‚Äòemployment profile switcher‚Äô.  Once they finish the onboarding process they land in Manage Pending Hires.

 

This process allows ‚ÄòCountry Transfer‚Äô to complete onboarding when SuccessFactors Recruiting is not enabled.

entry.title: Producer Event Mesh IFlow
entry.content:
Hi,

I would like for your opinion regarding designing producer's iflow for asynchronous data publishing and consumption. 
The general idea is to have integration flow that will iterate every 15 minutes over the list of datacenters and query Prometheus logs for every datacenter and then publish the data to the event mesh queue. That would be the producer iflow. Then, the consumer iflow would use the event mesh queue as the sender and push the messages to the FAST API application. 

So far I have been focusing on the producer design. It has the following steps:
1. Timer (trigger every 15 minutes)
2. Content Modifier (body with the landscape list)
3. Groovy script that reads the list
4. Iterator splitter (sequentially processing each landscape from the list)
5. Query Prometheus for each landscape id and build the topic property corresponding to the current landscape
6. Request Reply from the query
7. Publish the message to the event mesh queue
8. AMQP receiver adapter to connect to the queue
I would like your humble opinion on this design. I tested it and it works fine, the messages arrive to the queue and I can use Postman or Bruno to consume them. 
This is the setup with one queue and multiple topic subscriptions within the queue corresponding to each landscape id.
What do you think of this setup? I am using SAP Event Mesh and average message size can be from 2-5 MB depending on the size of the datacenter.

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: MFS - HU at the end of the automatic storage retrieva...
entry.content:
Hi,

 

from my point of view, the root cause of the issue is that you only have a waiting WT to move the HU to the next CP.
Because the WT is still in waiting/inactive status no subsystem relevance status is set in the WT and therefore the /SCWM/MFS_WT_DET_PREP will log the message "HU at the end of the automatic storage retrieval; sending not required. Technically, this corresponds to message /SCWM/MFS 230.

This message is being logged when you have  open/waiting WT with no subsystem relevance and your CP is either marked as an end point or a NIO-CP:

Whether a WT is subsystem-relevant depends on the queue determination. A WT only receives subsystem relevance "Y‚Äù if an MFS queue is determined:

The queue determination is only executed if 
  • your waiting WT will be set to active as the LOSC has no more intermediate bin needed
  • the LOSC finds the next intermediate bin and creates a new active WT to this intermediate bin
 
Therefore, you should check your LOSC customizing to understand why you end up with only a waiting WT instead of 
  • an active WT
  • or a newly created active WT to the intermediate bin + the remaining waiting/inactive WT to the final destination
